# Ideological (de-)Stigmatization

## Political Stigmatization and Preference Falsification

[@valentim_political_2023]

. . .

<br>

Traditional models of political behaviour are mostly based on [*intrinsic motivations*]{style="color:red;"}


![](question_mark.png){fig-align="center"}

## Political stigmatization

<br>

**Stigmatization** is proposed as an instance of [*extrinsinc motivations*]{style="color:red;"} modelling political behaviour

. . .

<br>


***Definition***

A situation in which individuals perceive that there is a [social norm]{style="color:red;"} against a given *political preference*


## The argument

<br>


Showing a ***stigmatized political preference*** can come at the cost of [social sanction]{style="color:red;"}. If the **costs of the sanction** are high enough, they may outweigh the **utility** that individuals derive from **expressing their sincere views**, leading to [preference falsification]{style="color:red;"} [@kuran1987preference; @kuran1998private]

## The Spanish case

. . .

Stigmatization of [***Partido Popular (PP)***]{style="color:blue;"}, formerly **AP**, for being a **succesor party**

## The empirical strategy


. . .

<br>

Leveraging one case where the **electoral system** differs, creating *exogenous variation* in the **visibility of the vote choice**


<br>

The *assumption* here is that **increasing the public visibility of the vote choice will decrease the likelihood of voting for PP** only because of the probability of a [sanction]{style="color:red;"} due to a [stigmatized preference]{style="color:red;"}

## Social norm change and expression of stigmatized preferences

[@dinas_social_2023]

<br>

. . .

Increased in [nationalism]{style="color:red;"}  typically explained as an outcome of **out-group threat**


![](question_mark.png){fig-align="center"}


## Out-group threat triggering norm erosion

<br>

**First-movers** break the [social norm]{style="color:red;"} which ***signals*** its weakening, thus further **eroding** it [(lower sanctioning costs)]{style="color:grey;"}

. . .

1. Increase of **public** expressions of nationalism

2. Stable **private** expressions of nationalism

3. How does **coordination** work?

## The Spanish case (II)

. . .

**Regime change** does not only bring the [stigmatization]{style="color:red;"} of political parties or ideologies [@dinas2020ideological], but it stigmatized the expression of [nationalism]{style="color:red;"} itself in Spain


![](flag_fascists.png){fig-align="center" width=60%}

<br>

1. *Establishing* the **increase of flags** after **1-O**

. . .

. . .

3. Proving **flags' display** as a [**coordination mechanism**]{style="color:red;"}
